fields.description: The ui team is using a cloud built from recent testing. I am unable to get BundleInstance to work either from boto using an existing bucket. 2014-07-17 22:42:40,135 boto [DEBUG]:Params: {'Storage.S3.Prefix': u'image', 'Storage.S3.AWSAccessKeyId': u'AKI8S0CX47WRULWNVUS6', 'Version': '2012-12-01', 'Action': 'BundleInstance', 'InstanceId': u'i-d335f1dd', 'Storage.S3.UploadPolicySignature': 'CH5FuHyzHE/nqrBdsNvbyLic7XY=', 'Storage.S3.UploadPolicy': 'eyJjb25kaXRpb25zIjogW3siYWNsIjogImVjMi1idW5kbGUtcmVhZCJ9LCB7ImJ1Y2tldCI6ICJhbmV3YnVja2V0In0sIFsic3RhcnRzLXdpdGgiLCAiJGtleSIsICJpbWFnZSJdXSwgImV4cGlyYXRpb24iOiAiMjAxNC0wNy0xOVQwMjo0Mjo0MFoifQ==', 'Storage.S3.Bucket': u'anewbucket'} 2014-07-21 17:18:33,455 boto [DEBUG]:InternalErrorError processing request: unable to find the access key signed the upload policy54045845-cc33-499d-9a40-7022b3468a07 Now, we're using session creds, not real creds. I suspect that affects a bucket access policy. Perhaps we can talk about specifically what is required. The Storage.S3.AWSAccessKeyId parameter is one thing, and I think that would need to be a permanent key (well, more permanent than a session cred). The other thing is the secret used to sign the policy. Can that be a session cred secret? I would not have access to the "permanent" secret. Furthermore, the account may not contain any permanent keys and so I could not include the access key in Storage.S3.AWSAccessKeyId. I would need to warn the user, or automatically create a key for them.

comments.body: This issue duplicates EUCA-9459.
I've removed the duplicates link after adding information to the "dupe" and revising this to address the real problem I have now which is different.

The more I think about this, the more I think we will have to support using session creds for bundling. Looping [~rusvika] in for security concerns. The console does not have access to the secret for the user, so it will be impossible to use that to sign the bucket upload policy. Since the bucket upload policy is just needed for the duration of the bundle operation, I think it would be acceptable to use temporary session creds to sign that.
The other issue is the access key supplied in the Storage.S3.AWSAccessKeyId parameter to BundleInstance. Does that need to be a long-term access key or can it be temporary? That's still an outstanding question in my mind.
[~spark], thoughts? Steve said you are the svs team guy I should talk to.
btw, posted in the AWS EC2 forum to get an "official" take on things; https://forums.aws.amazon.com/thread.jspa?messageID=558155&#558155

[~dkavanagh] [~sjones] I think you're right.. the session creds are not stored in database but the implementation of bundleInstance tries to match an access key in DB that supposedly generated the upload policy signature.

If we are looking up the credential for the current request then AccessKeys.lookupAccessKey can be used (passing in the security token). It is not possible to look up a temporary access key without the associated security token.

BundleInstance and POST policies do not include a way to supply STS tokens, and even if they did, you would have to be able to ensure that the creds you signed them with would not expire before the bundle task completes.

After talking with Sang-min:
- Cannot use session credentials for the AWSAccessKeyId param or to sign the upload policy
- Must create new access/secret so that we can use the secret to sign the upload policy
- Assume those keys must live as long as the bundle operation, but no longer (need to test this)
- We probably need to let user know not to delete these keys or bundle might fail. But, we might be able to delete them after register completes

If we are generating keys only for the bundling op, we should delete them after bundling completes (or is cancelled). Is there any reason to expose them to the user at all? I don't see one, please let me know if I am missing something (as I often am) :) 

[~gholms]: How do the CLI tools handle this issue?

The CLI tools use regular keys, not session keys, so this isn't an issue.
If we generate keys for the bundle operation, they would show up on the user detail page. The user has a chance to delete or deactivate the keys there which could negatively affect the bundle operation. That is why I wonder if we can completely hide the fact we create keys for bundling from the user. If we attempt to hide the keys in the console via some means, they would be  visible via euca2ools.
Another point is we can't support bundle-instance for AWS since we use session creds and session creds don't have access to IAM calls on AWS. This is potentially a big deal and we should consider how we will handle it.

Ah, I see, thanks for the info [~dkavanagh]. That makes sense.

At least we know what to do now. We need some way to protect the key from deletion by users while the bundle op is in progress (even from euca2ools)...is there a way to do that?

[~shashi], there may be a restriction in the UI against using bundle instance for AWS, which means we might not be able to create AMIs from instance store. May not be a show-stopper since they really promote EBS usage anyway. [~dkavanagh], we can talk about how to deal with this in the UI when you get back from vacay, but I would imagine we'd want to allow the user to select the menu option and if it's AWS and IS, pop up a message saying that operation is only supported for instances that have EBS root devices...thoughts?

No, there isn't a way to prevent authorized users from viewing or deleting specific keys.  Creating a new, long-lived keys would work on paper and probably work a lot of the time in practice, but it would have a few big effects that are worth considering:

# The console would have to start requiring people who want to use BundleInstance to _also_ have policies that allow them to use CreateAccessKey.  It is not unreasonable for someone to have permission to use EC2 operations but not IAM operations.
# IAM users are [limited to two active access keys at once|http://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/ManagingCredentials.html], so the console may not be able to create one even if the user has permission to do so.
# Implicitly creating an access key and hiding it will cause confusion for people who go to create access keys during a bundle operation and unknowingly bump up against that limit.
# The console's design would need to make it possible to eventually make reasonable guarantees about those long-lived access keys getting deleted in the event a single instance of the console fails.  This would likely require very little work beyond that already needed to deal with registering images after bundle tasks finish, but it _would_ cause that mechanism to become critical to security.

Here's my take on these things;
1. I think the only way to address permissions is to test this and let the user know if CreateAccessKey fails, giving them information about the permission the need to request.
2. Eucalyptus allows more than 2, but I can't say how many. Not sure if we plan to address this difference or call it a feature.
3. I am worried about how we inform the user about the keys created on their behalf. Open to suggestions
4. I've already stashed the access key (not secret) in the tag set I'm using to save values needed for register so that the code can delete that key.

Ugh, like so many things, the devil is in the details. :)

[~dkavanagh], we should test the perms for create access key as soon as they select the create image menu option for an IS instance, and notify them if they don't have the perms at that point. We don't want to let them go through all the config options on the dialog, only to find out it won't work. That way, also we can have the key in hand for the operation. We also need to clean up and delete the key for them when the bundle op is done, when move to the registration step. As long as euca supports >2 keys and we aren't doing this for AWS anyway, I am less concerned about that aspect. 

[~tvo], we should add something to the help for this page to indicate the access key creation and deletion associated with this operation for instance store backed images, please. This does not pertain to EBS-backed. We don't need to clutter the dialog itself with this info, since they will be tested, created and deleted for them, and if the user is in the GUI, they are unlikely to go to Euca2ools and delete them while the op is in flight.

I'll point out that if we create the key to test perms right away, there's a chance the user won't complete the operation and we'd be left with a stray key we didn't clean up since the user can navigate away.
In addition, we'd need to transfer the secret to the client side (which isn't great security when we only really want to keep it on the server for the duration of the policy signing). The reason we'd need to transfer to the client side is that the server can't hold that between when then select "create image" and when the submit the "create image" form.

Can you delete it after you create the test key, and then just create another one for the actual op? We need to keep the goal of transparency and simplicity for users at the top of our minds for this feature, and not exposing how the sausage is made is critical.
[~decker], [~jloza], [~dkavanagh], lets discuss this on the arch meeting tomorrow. Creating access keys should not be taken lightly, I'd like to make sure that's the only viable option.
Agreed. [~dkavanagh], I forwarded you an invite to the arch mtg for tomorrow.

If we decide to create access keys for them, we shoudl provide the ability to manually enter access keys if the create op fails, in the dialog informing them of the error. Try again with these keys, or ask your admin for a policy statement that gives you permission to create keys

I think we could mitigate the "multiple-bundling-task" problem by simply not allowing a 2nd bundle task when there is already one running for the instance. I don't think that is a bad limitation. Also, the tag limit problem could get in the way, but I suppose we could warn the user. Again, we'd be relying on that tag we use to stay in place (as well as the access key) or the bundle/register would fail.

One more problem. It has to do with using a tag to store the "tags" and block device mappings for the image. Tags have a limited length, but a single tag can never store a full set of 10 tags for an image if those image tags are somewhat long. The limit for those tags would be less than 1/10th of the normal length. Likewise, too many block device mappings will fill up the tag as well. One suggestion is to simply not allow tags to be added. Perhaps we could allow less tags (as in 1 or 2) and hope the aren't very long.
[~dkavanagh], let's chat today via phone and talk through these...
I'm closing this issue since there is no direct action on it. The solution is tracked in GUI-1100 and overall in GUI-1088

To me it looks that:
# There must be an access key/secret key in the account (otherwise there should be an error).
# The service operation BundleInstance is the only place where the access key/secret key can be accessed and have access to the policy in question.

These two imply that the service operation would need to account for this case (bundle instance w/ session keys) and re-sign the policy using the permanent access key/secret key or fail with an error when they do not.

[~sjones], can you consider this solution and suggest whether there is a better approach?

[~decker], We would have to check the credential type (TemporaryKeyType.Access) and only allow re-signing for console/impersonation credentials. These types of temporary credential do not require an access key for the user, so the action could still fail. I think the proposal would work if the user had access key credentials, but if they already have these credentials it would be preferable for them to use them directly.

The problem with using them directly is that the console does not support this. We don't keep the secret around and don't offer the user a way to authenticate with the console using the access/secret.
[~dkavanagh], the user is responsible for managing their credentials and using them when desired.

We did discuss giving the user the chance to enter an access/secret themselves, but the seamless UX experience is what Jenny's going for, which is why [~decker] suggested this trust conversion option.
Added sub-tasks for me to verify OSG/S3 compatibility with STS and POST uploads.

[~decker], [~dkavanagh], and [~sjones]:
I've concluded the quick investigation with the following results:

# POST uploads in Euca do support STS credentials
# Re-signing a policy on behalf of the user could work, but is more involved than previously thought because the token itself is part of the policy document, meaning the service would need to modify the policy document prior to re-signing. This is more involved than just recalculating a signature and a request parameter.

I would expect next steps include allowing an upload policy signed with session creds, and verifying that the bundle/upload process works in this case? There is still the issue with the creds expiring if the bundle/upload lasted longer than the creds (expiration) and handling that failure mode.

Session credentials can now be used when bundling instances. The security token used must be included in the upload policy as a condition using 'x-amz-security-token'.

The STS GetAccessToken action is updated to truncate the duration of credentials for admin users at one day, rather than the previous limit of one hour to so the credential expiry can more closely match the upload policy expiry.

This fix depends on a euca2ools update (TOOLS-511), which must be on the node controller.
Linked issue assigned to Steve Jones not complete. Removed bug from complete to close sprint.
[~dkavanagh], please try creating an access key for the user and see if it works then. It looks like an access key may be required for the S3 bucket check/create.
[~dkavanagh], I think you'd also need to put the "x-amz-security-token" and "acl" conditions in separate objects.

We had some IRC discussion and determined euca2ools on the NCs was tool old. That has been updated to latest master.
Before the NC's come into play, the bucket should be getting created and it is not. [~sjones], how would you like to proceed? I'll check in the UI code if that helps you test. (It's on the GUI-1088 branch of eucalyptus/eucaconsole).

The code fix for EUCA-9459 looks like it should work.
changing state till we sort this out.

Bundling an instance is currently failing when using temporary credentials in the case that the user does not have any active access keys for use accessing S3. The S3 bucket check / creation must be modified to allow for a user with only temporary credentials.
We no longer require a user to have a permanent access key credential for bucket check/creation when bundling an instance.

It now creates buckets when I use an account without access keys. In the cloud I just built, I see the bundle task failing in a short time, perhaps 15 seconds. The bucket is created, but empty. I get nothing else useful via the APIs. I'll check the logs next. The cloud I brought up today is again at 10.111.1.101
[~dkavanagh], please ensure you are using a version of euca2ools that supports this functionality on the NC (TOOLS-511)
Ah, yes, of course. My tests config still doesn't install that, so that must be it. I'll get that updated and retry.
I've tested this and so long as the latest euca2ools are installed on the NC, bundling works properly.
I bumped the eucalyptus-nc package's dependency to hopefully prevent the above problem from happening.
